Author: @2Good2BeTrue45
Comment:
Never liked Kratos reasoning that the choice between life and death when it came to Baldur killing Freya should have been Freya's choice to make. Her selfishness and self centered attitude made her think her getting killed by Baldur would have fixed anything, when in reality, it would have made Baldur even worse and make him a full blown sociopath on a warpath. Plus Freya needed to understand and see that while she lost Baldur, she was given Kratos and Atreus as a new family who deeply cared for her. Im glad they made her come to this realization by the end of the game but it still irks me how the game tried to make it seem at first cause Baldur NEEDED to be put down, even Odin admitted that Baldurs mind was long gone

Im so happy GNA put her in her place.

Gow shoots and letters on PS3 was better than this. Jake must have been high doing this review, because there's core combat mechanics that are missing and I'm like half way through the game. I felt myself fighting stay awake to play 2018, I find myself turning this game off every hour or so because I'm bored. 6/10 on steam sounds better than this game deserved tbh

Author: @YuniorGamboa
Comment:
The game tells a captivating story that, at times, may feel overly drawn out. It boasts breathtaking graphics and visceral animations. The combat feels better and faster than ever and engaging in combat with the spear provides a particularly gratifying experience, and the addition of free Valhalla DLC enhances the game's value. Players can also look forward to an array of enjoyable side quests and puzzles with great mini-bosses throughout its semi-open world.

On the downside, the game has some notable drawbacks:
- The inclusion of numerous Atreus missions can feel overwhelming and repetitive.
- The pacing of the story may seem oddly sluggish during certain segments, impacting the overall flow.
- Minor glitches within the game can detract from the immersive experience and when trying to quit the game, it would be stuck on the home menu saying it's already running. The only fix to this is restating the pc. It's annoying so day the leas. A few crashes here and there too
- It's worth noting that the companion often provides solutions to puzzles, potentially diminishing the challenge for players.
-Fighting that Gna Valkyrie was tough as a nail. DAMN
 - VALHALLA DLC KEPT CRASHING Constantly!! 
UNFORTUNATELY
   8/10

Author: @BenkaiDebussy
Comment:
I love how this video instantly mentions Hyperion Grapple. I also realized around 2/3 through the game that you can handle the vast majority of enemies by just grappling into them over and over again. With the right handle this often stuns them in one or two hits. So fights were just me slamming myself into guys and then doing stun kills to them.

Edit: This guy's videos are so good, they really put all other "gameplay tips" videos to shame

Author: @frompantohand2025
Comment:
There are actually "setups" to build up stun fast. One of them is to combine these skills
first, use blades: press L2+R2 (enemies turn their backs towards you) then do the Hyperion grapple, then keep pressing R1 to hit them in the back
Another is to throw the axe at the enemy's head, making them turn around and show their backs to you, them keep holding R1 to attack it multiple times with ice spikes

Author: @Matoakas
Comment:
One OP thing against multiple weaker enemies is the Light Ranged attack with the Blades (AIM/L2 + R1 on PS5). 

When you draw an enemy closer and into the ground so it goes airborne, 
you can slam that enemy into the enemies that get close (in front of you), and 'block' them from reaching you. 

They stagger when hit by the enemy you threw? sent? shot? the blade at. 
It's almost to easy at times if you do this. Especially if you combine it with Aim + R2 (heavy ranged attack with blades). 

Another thing that should be repeated for anyone that overlooked it:  
The Wretch nests are PERFECT for grinding Skill Labors, and the Wretch labor ofc. 
     They keep coming until you destroy the nest, so you can take a minute or ten whenever you are at a nest, 

and you'll have the skill perks in no time at all! 

I'm also sure ppl know to not waste resurrection stones, or go out of your way to find health.
If low on health and no health is near to pick up, just die. You reload with FULL HEALTH.  
 
Ofc, not in the arena, or if you are SO CLOSE to beat a boos, or if you are doing a NO DIE run. Then use the stone. 
But when FREE ROAMING.. Just die..

Teniendo esto en cuenta yo pienso que el eclipse que se ve puede ser el propio inicio de Ragnarok y el plan maestro de Atreus ser√≠a encontrar a los lobos para que vuelvan a perseguir el sol y la Luna pero en vez de hacerlo de Este hacia el Oeste, podr√≠a invertirlo de esta manera alterar√≠a el flujo temporal provocando una vuelta al pasado y dando pie a que el kratos y Atreus fueron los que tocaron el cuerno de la serpiente el GOW (2018) probablemente Atreus quiera cambiar algo del pasado con la ayuda del Jormungandr de hace 3 a√±os para cambiar el Ragnarok, podr√≠a ser bastante interesante explorar esa posibilidad.

Comment: Angrboda part was absolutely insufferable. Has nothing to do with there being a female or black character. It's the fact that it's God of War and this part felt like nothing more than a shoved in checklist and chore. It dragged on for about 2 and a half hours. Filled with berry picking, flower picking, skipping stones, and being lectured by a woman about how Atreus needs to learn to fight with his emotions......it's a section forced into the game to make a woman seem superior to a male and she has to teach him everything and boss him around. Author: @jasonlock884
Comment: This scene is more than it lets on in my opinion. Those who played the original God Of War games saw this man filled with nothing but rage and vengeance. Ready to kill at a moments notice and willing to kill anyone (innocent or not) who got in his way. A man who spoke with venom in his voice. We saw a man achieve his goal and end up as miserable as he was when he started. Then in God Of War 2018, we saw a man who was recovering from his past deeds. A man trying to ensure that his son did not follow in his footsteps. A man trying to come to terms with what he has done. We see more of that in God Of War Ragnorok. But when it came to God Of War Valhalla, this is where we see his redemption arc come full circle. We see him enduring his past dealings and reliving them. Being reminded of the way he destroyed everything in a selfish endeavor. But when we reach this scene, things change. We see him finally confront the one he hated more than anything else in the world. The man he used to be. But rather than refilling with anger, he finally comes to an unexpected conclusion. He was much more than a destroyer. Much more than a stone cold killer. He has always been more. And he has now realized that he can forgive the man he used to be. It‚Äôs honestly so hard hitting. And you really don‚Äôt expect it to be.

Author: @bass-tones
Comment:
To a degree I don't blame people, but far too many have rose-tinted glasses when it comes to GoW 2018. Now don't get me wrong; it's a masterpiece, and an amazing game, especially in the context in which it released in. But people also overlook its flaws. 2018 also has massive pacing issues. You can practically feel the time and budget running out right in front of you as you play the final third of the game.

I also respect that 2018 is telling a simple, intimate story. But to me it's hard to not see behind the curtain and understand that was likely done _both_ as a scope and budget limitation and as a story device. The world feels so, so small in 2018. It literally feels like you, the dwarves, Freya, and Baldur, are the the only people who live in the entire game universe.

Ragnarok has a few pacing issues of its own, but it improves so massively on the obvious flaws of 2018 that it's hard for me not to see it as just the superior game. The story is brilliant as well. It's just as intimate and thorughtful as 2018, but with even more layers and character dynamics, and has in my opinion one of the best-realized twists in all of media that also boosts the game's replayability.

It feels like the scope of the rest of the game was cut back, because a ton of resources were put here and I think they should have pulled it back about 30%.  Never make a map like that again.

Author: @dante93nero
Comment:
I think God of War Ragnarok will always suffer from the fact it was the sequel to God of War 2018. For me personnally the story in Ragnarok is better since it's developing more plot points and you can see multiple characters change & adapt (Thor is a big example). 

I do feel Atreus side of the game will always bring the game down even though (except Ironwood which did felt slow) most of the quests were useful to understand Odin/Thor's motives & reasons for why they are who they are.

The shield mechanics to me are a clear upgrade from the first game since it adds another layer of depth to the combat.

I also agree that I was expecting the final battle to be a bit longer and, again, I do feel that Santa Monica screwed themselves here because of how massive the world is. I don't quite remember the realm, but there is a random favor that literally takes you to an entire new zone that has like 10-15 hours of gameplay put into it it's crazy.

other than the story god of war ragnarok is still a worthy sequel and better.

The one thing I can think of at the moment is that some of the berserker fights are very braindead and extremely badly designed. Like the one with the three sisters.
And some combat mechanics are really.. uhh. NIche, Not really needed and doesn't add anything of value, (**IMO**)
Edit: I didn't really enjoy Valhalla's gameplay much, maybe because I'm bad at the game (lol) but the story depth of kratos was very worth it and made up for the lack of it in the main game

God of War Ragnar√∂k is perfect to me, it is better to me than RDR2 and i thougt no game would ever be better than it. Let me tell you my side of the Story.


When GOW3 released i saw it everywhere on social media, and in Newsletters. I remembered this Year in August that i didn't bought the PS 5 Version for this Game and i put another 10 ‚Ç¨ in the Game for the PS 5 Edition, just to Platinum it all over again and Grinded the Valhalla DLC.

Author: @zaster154
Comment:
I don‚Äôt usually comment on videos, but this one‚Äôs an exception since you‚Äôre a smaller creator, and I think feedback could be helpful. Hope you don‚Äôt take this the wrong way because I actually found the video really fun to watch and want to encourage you to keep making more content like this!

That said, I have a few thoughts:

First off, you talk about the game like you‚Äôre trying not to spoil it for the viewers‚Äîsaying things like, ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt give too much away‚Äù‚Äîbut the video is essentially a retrospective packed with spoilers. This makes no sense.

Some of your critiques were solid, but others left me scratching my head:
- UI: I didn‚Äôt like the UI either, but mainly because it feels like a design we‚Äôve seen in tons of other games. Meanwhile, you criticize the information the UI provides, but then go on to praise the UI in GOW 2018‚Äîwhich delivers the exact same information?

- Shields: I‚Äôm confused about your dislike for the shields in GOW:R. They add variety and improve the gameplay loop compared to the first game. Plus, you can still use the same shield mechanics from the first game if you prefer. Simply saying the shields in the first game were better doesn‚Äôt really explain your point, especially when the sequel offers more depth.

I also feel like you could‚Äôve gone deeper with your story critique. Sure, the game has pacing issues‚Äîthat‚Äôs fair and widely acknowledged‚Äîbut what about the actual story? Were there storybeats you didn‚Äôt like besides seperating Kratos and Atreus? What about Freya's reconsiliation with Kratos? The death of Brok and that story with Sindri? Did the story feel overly complex/bloated compared to the first game? And how about the side quests‚Äîdid they feel like an improvement over GOW 2018?

By the end of the video, I was left wondering about your thoughts on all these aspects. Instead you kept in line with the same tired critique of Atreus sections being long... Anyway, just some constructive feedback to think about. Looking forward to seeing more from you!

Spoilers




I do think the pacing was my biggest issue, like we spent 2 hrs with angraboda and her issues with her grand mum but like 30 minutes with thor who's one of the most important characters in the story. 

A more personal issue i have is Atreus? Like I feel like his depiction in this second games makes perfect sense where he's older more impulsive and wants to make his own decisions which he does and has a whole section grieving on his mistakes which then a third game he would have his Return of the jedi moments of showing his growth.

But then it just kind of rushes to him being a developed adult and hero whose learned from his mistakes and single handedly saves the day and then ends on him standing on a cliff ready for his adventure to save the giants and I just didn't feel convinced?
But hey that's my opinion many felt it was earned and I definitely wouldn't want to doom the developers into another 5 years of game development when they truly felt they could do it in one. So in the end I'm satisfied with what we got

Author: @sydneyhunter2807
Comment:
Helpful tip if you're struggling with endgame ng+ and higher and are having difficulty with the endgame bosses one thing that will help out the most is once you've completed as much as you can on the first couple of playthroughs you'll want to focus on getting all Yggdrasil Dew (9) once done
You'll want to open all Nornir Chests (48) 
If you focus on this alone and can bare going through the game over and over as fast as you can like a Speed run you'll eventually start to notice a big Difference in Difficulty completely allowing you to choose freely on what you want to use and still reck everything.

Author: @E45F678
Comment:
Hey everyone, I thought I'd share something cool. I had a few ideas about where the next GoW game could go, so I made a summary up for ChatGPT and it turned out the following:
**Setting:** The bustling streets of Cairo, Egypt, are awash with the golden hues of dusk. Ancient structures blend with the vibrant life of the city, creating a fascinating juxtaposition of old and new. Kratos, Mimir, and Freya, having traversed realms and braved countless dangers, finally arrive at a hidden oasis outside the city where Atreus has been residing.

---

**Kratos**: *(Eyes scanning the surroundings with a mix of curiosity and relief)* "We've reached the place. Is this truly where Atreus chose to be?"

**Freya**: *(Nodding as she takes in the exotic landscape)* "It appears so. I never thought I'd see him in such a far-off land."

**Mimir**: *(His eyes brightening with anticipation)* "Ah, the lad's grown fond of the Egyptian lands, it seems. I wonder what stories he‚Äôs gathered here."

**Atreus**: *(Emerging from behind a large stone column, his face lighting up upon seeing his father)* "Father! Freya! Mimir! You're here!" *(He rushes forward, embracing Kratos tightly. Freya and Mimir follow, sharing heartfelt greetings)*

**Kratos**: *(Returning the hug with a rare softness)* "Atreus... you look well. I see you've made a home here."

**Atreus**: *(Stepping back with a grin)* "Yes, and I've learned so much. Let me show you what I've discovered." *(He leads them to a small, shaded area where a collection of mystical artifacts and scrolls is laid out)*

**Freya**: *(Examining the items with keen interest)* "What is all this?"

**Atreus**: *(Holding up a shimmering, translucent orb)* "These are the soul marbles of the Jotnar giants. With the help of Anubis, I've learned how to manipulate soul magic. It‚Äôs through these marbles that I‚Äôve found a way to restore Brok's missing soul pieces to the Lake of Souls in Alfheim."

**Mimir**: *(Impressed and curious)* "By the Nine Realms, lad, that‚Äôs incredible! Anubis, you say? Quite a potent ally."

**Kratos**: *(Eyes narrowing slightly)* "Restoring Brok's soul... you truly believe it can be done?"

**Atreus**: *(Nodding earnestly)* "Yes. I‚Äôve studied the rituals and magic closely. It‚Äôs a complicated process, but I believe it‚Äôs possible. However, we'll need Sindri‚Äôs help to complete it."

**Freya**: *(Frowning slightly)* "Sindri... after everything that happened, do you think he‚Äôll agree to help us?"

**Atreus**: *(Sighing)* "It won‚Äôt be easy. He‚Äôs still hurting from Brok‚Äôs death and the fallout from Odin‚Äôs attack. But I think it‚Äôs worth trying. We owe it to Brok and to ourselves to make things right."

**Kratos**: *(Nods thoughtfully)* "Then we must find him. If there‚Äôs a chance to set things right, we will take it."

**Mimir**: *(Cheerfully)* "Aye, let‚Äôs not waste any more time. We have a long journey ahead, but if anyone can convince Sindri to help, it‚Äôs you, lad."

**Freya**: *(Smiling gently at Atreus)* "We‚Äôre with you, Atreus. Together, we‚Äôll do what we can."

**Atreus**: *(Grateful, he begins packing up the soul marbles and other artifacts)* "Thank you all. I knew we could make this work if we stuck together."

---

**Scene transitions:** The group sets off in search of Sindri. Their shared resolve and newfound hope create a sense of unity and purpose, promising a chance at redemption and the restoration of lost souls.

Author: @uncleiroh0989
Comment: What an incredible series. I've never played these games but was interested in the story of Kratos. To say I wasn't disappointed would be an understatement--I LOVED watching this series! Following his path to vengeance against Zeus and all the pain that he went through was beyond satisfying, which is something I love about these games. They care about their story, their fans, and make sure that older and newer fans are well-rewarded. GoW 4 was amazing to see, especially because I relate to a lot of the concepts explored in that in my own life--starting a new journey, losing what family I used to have, and creating a new life for myself all while meeting new people and finding a new family. It's powerfully-written and brought me to tears many times. Ragnarok was incredible as well--aside from a lot of the Atreus/Loki levels--and wrapped everything up amazingly. I can't wait to see what's next, and maybe I'll even play it this time.

Author: @Moose0fNorway
Comment:
This game was worked on by sweet baby inc.

-The Queen Valkyrie uses the word "patriarchy" in her dialogue.
-Freya defeats Kratos in a fight and saves him multiple times, including during a key boss battle.
-Thor is portrayed as an overweight drunk with father issues, and Odin as a corrupt capitalist.
-The game features a mission involving a race-swapped character and a diverse cast, which the writer notes.
-There is less brutality, violence, and gore compared to previous games.
-Kratos shows vulnerability, is apologetic, and is less proactive, mainly reacting to events.
-The game includes a climate change-related side quest.
-Freya is portrayed as strong, and Kratos‚Äô wife is described as being dominant in their relationship.
-The final battle with Odin is shared with Freya, who delivers a key blow.

Author: @DaneofHalves
Comment:
This game ended up being mediocre. It has several moments of greatness with plenty of wow factor but the looming shadow of unskippable horridly written story beats are too hard to ignore. They are very much speed bumps in a runway for this game and prevented it from taking off in my opinion. From B storylines with Atreus that don't fit the M rated nature of God of War games to all the backseating chatter that you can't turn off from companion characters, to miscast performances from Odin and Heimdall(Both of them felt like gas store clerks rather than gods), The rushed battle of Ragnarok, The abrupt death of Thor, To Sindri being written as a contemptable a** to his friends after his brother dies, to being sucked into the mask "mystery box" trope with no resolution or explanation of that mystery(basically a carrot on a stick), to a bait and switch regarding Tyr who was talked about so much in the previous game but ended up being a no show in a game that should have explored his character and involved him more. (Maybe that is why we got the free DLC because of this reason. Fans were not happy about a false Tyr.)

This game had lots of issues and feels like another "Ascension" game fiasco. This one should have gone through a better quality assurance team before being released. Because the gameplay, set pieces, art, sound and combat mechanics have all improved. The boss battles are very memorable and fun. The side quests were a little more fun and interesting. A little more exploration and beserker challenges were top notch.

But the issues I brought up drug it down and this game ended up being about average. In fact, I'm really not interested in any future GoW games if this is the kind of thing we will be getting. This game should have been a shoe-in for Game of the Year but lost to a FromSoft game that is notorius for "item storytelling" which is the worst and laziest kind of story telling. It was a hell of a game from an exploration/graphic/fight mechanic stand point but shouldn't have won GotY over GoWR. 

But it did because of all the terrible flaws in Kratos' latest outing. Even the original creator of God of War didn't like this game. Focus groups and market research needs to be taken more seriously down there in southern cali.

Author: @Slowdough99
Comment: Seems a shame in hindsight to have those combat iterations the way he did while not being able to speak on Draupnir. The emotional significance and heritage connection that moment carries and the emotions you feel as a player in this grand finale of Kratos after all these years and after the Blades half way into 2018, to be on the last 3rd of this game and aquire the weapon and really on item Kratos owns that signifies who he truly is when you strip his tired life away.......a born warrior. A Spartan. A man loyal in life and death to those in his charge, and the 3 way weapon swapping and range option it tosses into the combat at that stage is remarkable. I dont use hyperbole in life or get caught up in nostalgia. In my honest opinion in terms of playing a video game, the Draupnir Spear is on completely even footing with Levathian and the blades. And that's something not spoken about enough. Most melee action games have 10 weapons etc. Santa Monica has successfully created 3 ICONIC weapons that when you see and play with you only think Kratos. A 3rd weapon could have been so phoned it. A Thors hammer type of debacle. Instead they did something far better.

Anyway, just surprised for the universal praise. And im a big fan of the first game.

Author: @NutsorSomethingBerserk
Comment:
SPOILERS:



God of War 4 was about Kratos learning how to be a good father.

God of War Ragnarok was about Kratos learning how to be a good man.

At first, I wasn‚Äôt as connected to God of War 4 as everyone else was whenever it was released. I played it to completion and even beat the Valkyrie Queen and many of the side activities. I had fun and liked the story but for some reason it didn‚Äôt connect with me yet like it did for everyone else at it‚Äôs release. 

Now having completed Ragnarok and am working on 100% it, I finally understand. I look back now at God of War 4 with nothing but admiration and playing this title has made me wanna go back and re-experience it with my new found perspective on this duology. 

These 2 titles but Ragnarok in particular are absolute masterpieces. Previous to this game, I was a very casual GOW fan. I played the OG trilogy and 4 but none of them stood as all time favorites in my head. I loved them all for different reasons though. However, Ragnarok did something incredibly special. The God of War trilogy was about a man pushed to his breaking point and beyond being used as a tool, a pawn, and whenever he out lived his usefulness the gods threw him in the trash. That very man sought revenge and got it. Didn‚Äôt matter what collateral damage was in his way. As long as those who wronged him were punished by his hands. Once it was all said and done, he destroyed everything around him. He became a utter monster. God of War 4 began this journey of towards trying to move beyond his past. Live the normal life he never got to lead back in Greece and just find peace. It started his path of redemption and Ragnarok completed it for Kratos. 

The theme of both of these games are ‚ÄúBeing Better‚Äù and with God of War 4, I loved what they did with the plot and the characters there but they only felt like it was halfway there to me, not the whole picture. Kratos became a good father to Atreus but he still felt like he was missing the push to be a good man. He‚Äôd help with freeing the Valkyries and a handul of other things but it was always either out of reluctance or because Atreus would steer the ship. He hadn‚Äôt yet completed his own personal journey towards redemption.

In Ragnarok however, Kratos is by the end of the game, a much better man. Hell, even a hero to the norse world. And he acts as such too. Not just for Atreus. For himself. And for those around him. For Freya, Mimir, etc. He‚Äôs doing what he does to help others because HE wants to. And the moment whenever he saw Faye‚Äôs final mural and cried, I also started sobbing. 

The character development they‚Äôve put Kratos through, someone who was downright monstrous and destroyed the entire greek pantheon just for revenge, innocents be damned, to a man who saved as many people as he could throughout Ragnarok, helped his son find himself, made several friends and companions and helped them on their own personal journeys, saved the realms, and after his mission with Ragnarok was accomplished, he continues to pursue making the norse world a better place and repairing the damage that Odin left in his wake.

Kratos from beginning to end went from a sympathetic but cold hearted man driven by his pursuit of revenge to a genuine hero. And when Kratos realized that‚Äôs what Faye wanted and/or saw him as, it showed him and us that he always had it in him to BE a hero. 

Sorry if I‚Äôm reiterating a lot of things, I just needed to get this off my chest as I just completed this game hours ago.

Ragnarok single handedly made God of War one of my favorite gaming franchises and not only did this game live up to my every expectation, it surpassed all of them. In gameplay, level design, and ESPECIALLY narrative. My only disappointment with this title is that I can no longer play it for the first time ever again.

What a game. What a journey. Kratos was already awesome. But his journey with Atreus has solidified him in my eyes as one of the best protagonists in gaming. Next to characters like Arthur Morgan.

Author: @Zordetto
Comment: The reviews by Skillup are too well done and show way too much content.  It's to the point I can't even watch them until I have finished the game in question to decide for myself.  What I don't think he realizes is that to some people, showing some of the most beautiful cutscenes of the game, and footage from various boss fights are, in fact, spoilers.  Don't get me wrong, there was a ton he didn't get into that he could have, but if you make a video this long, and go into as much vivid and well described detail as Skillup does, odds are you're going to be seeing something really cool the game has to offer for the SECOND time on your first playthrough of the game....because you already saw it here first.  I think two things are true here:  1: Skillup makes the most entertaining reviews.  2:  You shouldn't  watch them before you play a particular game if you'd like to discover some amazing content on your own, as opposed to this channel.

Author: @theblackknight101
Comment:
I wish the writers actually see this only to learn where they made mistakes and improve upon them for their next entry.. hopefully.

EDIT: Dialogues with quips have no excuse after it has been criticised to death in every place it is used.. so unfortunately lazy.

Also, didnt mention the fight with the bifrost sorcerer berserker in the other frozen world (niflheim?).. that fight was so much more toxic than it needed to be that I quit the game.. didnt even fight the berserker king. 

The "double-blue-circle" shield-bash/parry indicators were also something I was not a fan of.. most parries stopped feeling rewarding because the game kept telling me most attacks couldn't be parried at all. 

Then the repeat boss fights with "The Hateful" were the worst ever.. again because most normal mechanics for other similar sized enemies refused to work for these.. its attacks just phased through all player attacks/defences (infinite poise, seems like) and stun locked Kratos while also burning etc.. overall pain unless over levelled, at which point why bother for just another blade upgrade?

Also, please stop complaining so much about haters.. I truly believe they are in the minority and most people are here to listen, to give your point of view a fair shot, and even critiques can have disagreements/discussions, but constant whining about these negative comments is not fun to listen to when I'm here for long-form content about a game. If its such a problem, address it in a separate video/community post please. STOP MAKING YOUR ACTUAL CONTENT OBJECTIVELY WORSE TO LISTEN TO. I dont mind minor updates about your life or anything positive you have to share, but whining/negativity about non-review related stuff needs to stay separate.

Author: @lukathefae3904
Comment:
I agree with the pacing issues and some of the other points made about exploration, but the point about prophecy and fate being things that can be broken are found in the first game. 
One of the main ones being Magni and Modi in the prophecy of Ragnar√∂k are supposed to survive, but you kill both of them before the Fimbulvetr in Midgard even starts. 
Then after coming back from the realm of the giants Mimir says that by killing Baulder, Kratos has caused Fimbulvetr to come 100 winters too early.
Even if they aren't very obvious both of these events are Kratos braking prophecy/fate. Especially the Magni and Modi bit the only thing those two are known for is surviving Ragnar√∂k so I think it's obvious that from the start fate being broken was going to be a part of the story in one way or another.

Author: @darkphoenix2
Comment:
I finally put this game down after a couple months and a few final days bashing my head against the wall in Valhalla, trying to unlock the Rond of Obliteration. Dumbest challenge I've ever attempted in a game. Mastery difficulty feels straight up broken, like the enemy animations are lying to you about when to dodge or parry.

Oh, yeah, anyway...I hated the story. 2018 was pretty good, even if it was a big chain of McGuffin chases needed to propel the characters to the next emotional beat. But this game was a mess in so many ways. I honestly don't think I could retell it with any detail. I'd just have to summarize it as "Atreus keeps doing stuff and Kratos is along for the ride until he kills Thor and Odin to save everybody". The big shocking moment with Odin being Tyr all along made no damn sense. I don't understand the point of Atreus' soul marbles and him saying goodbye to Kratos by running off the screen at the end. So many emotional moments feel forced now, with characters constantly sharing each others wisdom as if it's a contest to see who is the most mentally stable. The modern, human way these gods and goddesses are portrayed doesn't really work for me, like Freya talking about how much Odin being an abusive husband affected her. It just doesn't land when she's literally one of the most powerful beings in that world.

I dunno, I could go on and on. The writing just wasn't that good.

One thing in common amongst the haphazard plot points everywhere is the messaging that impales the game industry.. Artreyus throws fits, goes to the enemy and gets his way in the end. 

A violent real world lessons scene like Omni man & Mark Greyson would have been BAD ASS. Maybe Artreyus eviscerates a boss more than Modi to save Kratos. Instead of nameless creatures. Kratos comforts him and leads him to pursue peace. But thats against the message. People who yell and whine get their way is what we're shown. Odin's behavior was phoned in and made no sense

It's pathetic to the legacy of our characters but who knows if it can even be fixed. It's being pushed on us as a religion.  Enjoy the 45minute Yak ride & Mary jane scene

Individual character interactions feel mostly well written and acted, but the plot itself just isn‚Äôt executed well. It feels like they tried to cram two games into one. If this game had been about Fimbulwinter with Freya and potentially Thor acting as primary antagonists while fleshing out the pantheon of gods, and subtly building to certain threads hinted at in 2018, ending at the point where Brok dies, and Freya is made a reluctant ally, it would have been ace. Ragnarok itself, and the joining of the realms needed its own 20 - 30 hours of run; the  40 minutes of it we got was well done, but not enough.

Author: @RaptorMM
Comment: I loved the game. Absolutely. The character journey and arc of Cratos and Atreus is just amazing. The idea that hope and love have the power to save lives and even worlds, to change destiny, that is a powerful idea! Kratos had to learn to be a god, but learning to be a good father, role figure, husband, partner, friend... This was his true journey... And he has overcome everything and has become worthy in every way possible. He did many unspeakable and evil deeds but he learned that change is possible, that change is good. He forgave himself, he fought and became the best he could ever be. The best father, the best friend, the best god he could be. That, I think, is a very good message to every of us. That we can always change our ways, that we can always be better, for us, for our children. I somehow connect this story with Sarah Connor's "No Fate" in The Terminator... We write our own story, we decide. No prophecy decides for us. Now that is a strong message!

Author: @davidmichael9275
Comment:
Its one thing for this game to be garbage. I think we all knew once Sony moved its HQ to california their quality would go down and politics would be inserted. A disappointing game was a safe bet. 
What is inexcusable is this game shitting all over 2018. 
What do i mean?
The central theme of Ragnarok is the idea that you're not beholden to prophecy. You can break prophecy. 
Angrboda is told she'll never be more than a character in Lokis's story, and she fights against that. 
Kratos knows he's supposed to die and fights against that. 
Loki knows he's supposed to team up with Odin and fights against that. (Kinda)
The problem is, this idea completely fucks 2018. 
If prophecy means nothing,  then Faye making the murals depicting everything that happened in 2018 means nothing. 
The only reason Atreus is Loki is because of the giants' prophecy but apparently that means nothing. 
Ragnarok IS A PROPHECY. If prophecy doesn't matter, then why have a ragnarok at all?
If you can just CHOOSE not to follow prophecy, then why does Atreus have to be Loki at all?
Was 2018 a prophecy or was Faue just a good guesser?
The game wants to have it both ways. 
The characters absolutely HAVE to do certain things because thats what the proohecy says, but at multiple points they decide "nah, prophecy doesn't matter, well just be better" and completely shit on the idea of prohecy. 
The mural at the end of 2018 is what made that game so special. We learned that everything we had done was all foretold, and the story had been decided for us long ago. It was an amazing moment. 
Then we see that Kratos dies. This has weight because everything else that the giants predicted came true, so we had to assume that this would too. 
Then Ragnarok decides nah, its all just choice. The murals, the stories, and the legends were all just lucky guesses. 
Ugh.

Author: @Lessthanthreeedm
Comment:
Just beat the main game + the DLC 100%, but not sure how I feel about Ragnarok compared to the previous release. Without thinking too much about it I can say this:

Pros: 
‚Ä¢ Felt like there's much more to explore and collect.
‚Ä¢ A lot of stuff happening in terms of the story, even though sometimes it felt a bit too rushed. DLC story was kinda nice as well.
‚Ä¢ Nice to play with different companions.
‚Ä¢ A lot of new and old, likeable characters.
‚Ä¢ Nice addition to rage choices.
‚Ä¢ Spear?

Cons:
‚Ä¢ Really dumbed down combat and its difficulty even on the Give me God of War.
‚Ä¢ Atreus arcs and especially the 3 hours of bs in the woods with Angrboda (ü§Æ).
‚Ä¢ Super lazy DLC design. Like who wants to play the same level over and over again? I'd rather do the Muspelheim trials than that shit.
‚Ä¢ So many cool options in DLC armor selection, but the main game armor sets were kinda mid.
‚Ä¢ Some levels are just from God of Puzzles instead of God of War.

Author: @medalgear654
Comment:
the game is awful. The story feels like a bad CW drama, with Atreus being an annoying, self-righteous brat. His decisions feel like they‚Äôre there just to stir up cheap drama. And the dialogue? Straight-up MCU cringe, constantly undercutting the serious tone. Even Kratos is out of character‚Äîhe spends the whole game avoiding war when we know the real Kratos would be preparing for it.

The worst part is they tried so hard to add ‚Äúdepth,‚Äù but the series already had depth! It didn‚Äôt need all this forced emotional drama. They basically rewrote history, acting like the older games were just mindless violence when they were already complex. And Odin and Thor? Built up as these terrifying forces in the 2018 game, but in Ragnarok, they‚Äôre reduced to a mob boss and a drunken brute with daddy issues. It‚Äôs such a jarring shift that it makes their buildup feel wasted. The story drags on with unnecessary subplots and cringe-worthy moments, and the characters suffer because of it.

On top of that, the game constantly takes control away from you with long, unskippable cutscenes where you can only walk around. And Atreus‚Äô levels? Total pacing killers. You can‚Äôt even properly properly explore until you beat the final boss. Ragnarok just feels too restricted, too cinematic, and it misses the mark with its messy story and watered-down characters.

It‚Äôs not a boring game, the soundtrack was fantastic but compared to the classics and even God of War 4, it‚Äôs a huge step back.

Author: @steverainingagain7956
Comment:
I'm surprised at the Kratos being nerfed narrative. I think the only thing I found underpowered was  Spartan Rage, and I only really used it to get health. However you have 3 different weapons for the majority of the game, each with 2 seperate runic attacks. If you play it correctly you pretty much have runic attacks available at all times. Thats not to mention Atreus runic (I use the wolves) and your relic (Bifrost one is really good). 

Having finished the game my only regret was that I did it on No Mercy instead of GOW difficulty. Would have stretched the game time and made the big fights feel more significant. Other than a handful of Berserkers and the trials of Musphelheim (these were probably hardest part of the game), I got through most fights with ease thanks to the high availability of runic attacks. Even Odin and Thor only took me like 2/3 tries

Author: @schools6555

Finding the right piece of wood to shape into the handle was challenge enough. I took many hikes to find it, which was White Birch I found in the White Mountains of New Hampshire. I wish i could post a picture of it with this long drawn out comment.

Author: @curiousconsultant7922
Comment:
[Spoiler] The ragnarok invasion was the only let down for me. We had spent 2 games with Mimir drilling our ears about the end of times, the war to end all wars, and they foreshadowed how Kratos would have to pick up his general's banner in the end but did so little with it.

I would have had Kratos take charge of the Raganrok army at the start of the final act and then have the player do the tour of the relms to rally everyone and then have a huge war room meeting planning the assault  only for the final mission to play out kindof like medeval strategy warfare but without actual troops management on the player's part.
Maybe even have Kratos not be on the front line right away but instead you play as Atreus carrying out the general's orders along with everyone else. Only for Ktratos to jump in as the much needed reinforcment showing Odin "the god he once was".

So utimatly the ending was rushed a litttle after having such a slow pace. Another option would've been to have this game be called something else and end with a failed invasion where Surtr doesn't show up. And then have a third game that's all about the Ragnarok war which could be a long term battle split accross the realms (kinda like Mass Effect 3)

Author: @BahamutBreaker
Comment:
Very solid guide! I remember your Forbidden West videos ‚Äî which were truly outstanding. Glad to see you have some solid content for other fun games, too! I think the best piece of advice I can offer here (to players) is to try getting accustomed to BOTH the Dauntless Shield and the Stonewall Shield. They behavior of the two shields (and the play-styles they mesh with) are very different. Being able to competently switch (in the character subscreen) between the shields, depending on the type of enemy you‚Äôre fighting, is a BIG advantage for the player, in my opinion.
Later in the game, some enemies have very annoying attack combos that feature repeated ‚Äúyellow-ring‚Äù attacks ‚Äî each with *different* delay times between the yellow-ring and the actual execution of the attack. The Stonewall Shield is great in those situations, providing forgiveness if you mistime a Parry. However, in other situations, where the enemy‚Äôs yellow-ring attack timing is more predictable and manageable, the Dauntless Shield is way better.

Author: @grimm6jack
Comment:
Really nice walkthrough once again. You really are an inteligent gamer, for the newbies and less experienced players, this really is the best early game build.

For the people who are veterans at GoW 2018 and mastered the parry and dodge and also the timing of your attacks, forget about any other stat but strength, especially if you play in Give Me God of War difficulty. Yeah, you will die a lot to get used to the new enemies attacks, but once you have them figured out, it will feel extremely satisfying to beat them fast while not receiving any damage. That's the way to beat enemies actually, focus on not getting damage while also focusing on maximizing your attack power to kill enemies faster, since the faster you kill the enemies, the probability of you making a mistake over time is also less. If the builds give you the nice perks like Realm Shifts, extra strenght while in a XX% HP state, or something else, that's a bonus.
As usual, high risk, high reward.

The game itself in the shops allows you to select which builds are more focused on each stat, a really nice touch and QoL improvement that makes it so much easier to choose your build according to your playstyle.

I'm currently end-game right now, but compared to how Horizon did its sequel in terms of gameplay mechanics, which IMO were very good overall, GoW was just a step ahead, while not having nearly as much "clutter" as Horizon had in terms of outfits and weapons.

Personally, I stuck with the full Nidavellir armor set all the way to the endgame!

With the gauntlets and waist, inflicted stun damage basically never goes down! Combined with the chest armor's perk to regain health on every stun grab, this makes for an excellent tank build!

Author: @RickyBobby-me7sr
Comment: To me it feels like I'm pressing the default dodge button(X) the most overall in battles sooooo I think Santa Monica decided the X button would be superior to the circle button for dodges and the important parts of game play. Otherwise, you'd only press X for menus and interactions. The X button becomes a much better choice for dodging because we are more accustomed to pressing that button for important reasons and not just for interactions. I swapped X and circle early on my playthrough, but I soon swapped back. I realized that even though I am used to using the circle button to dodge in most games, I would find myself bashing the X button in dire circumstances over the circle button to survive. X felt better when I needed my character to do something while squeezing my controller in certain death.

Author: @Vitalserum
Comment: My key learning: understand power levels and health bar colors. The single most important factor that defines how much damage you do (and take) is your power level. It's not your skills, your stats or any other character tweaks. The game doesn't tell you that it grants huge attack & defence buffs if you are at a higher level than your enemy (green health bar).  Likewise, it'll give you a huge debuff if you're fighting a higher-ranked enemy (orange, purple or red health bars). Yellow means the same gear level, these enemies are usually quite easy as well. So much so that it actually doesn't really matter what kind of build you have, what matters most is that your equipped gear is leveled up. It's a bit of a workaround by the Game to manage difficulty progression, but also cheapens the whole character progression imho.

Author: @chaseowens9627
Comment: I somewhat get what he means but at the same time he said it very negatively. He wants his character to be a specific way because that‚Äôs how he intended the character to be. It‚Äôs understandable to be annoyed that your work is being altered into something you didn‚Äôt want. But at the same time his reasoning makes no sense as he seems to completely and utterly forget that God of War had family as one of the major core aspects of the franchise in a LOT of ways. Kratos killed his wife and daughter after being tricked which literally led to EVERYTHING happening. Kratos spend almost his whole life up to that point thinking his mother and brother were dead and that he had no father. He later finds out that Zeus the one and only true target for Kratos aside from Aries is his father which adds another level of complexity. Hell Kratos even struggles to let Pandora into the flame because he begins to view her similarly to his own daughter that he misses. The dude used his dead wife‚Äôs bracelet as a form of coping through illusion based torture and ground his mind back in reality. He gave up ALL of his godhood and even his actual life to be in the fields (afterlife) with his daughter before having to leave her there so he can stop all of creation from being destroyed killing everything and everyone permanently. Lratos saved his brother after spending years thinking he was dead just to watch him ACTUALLY be murdered right in front of him furthering his rage for the gods. Literally over and over and over the plot and story is driven further by family and family relations. Even other gods get involved due to Kratos killing their family members for getting in his way.

Author: @ethanbezzina1887
Comment:
In my opinion, changing a character after a long period of time is fine (and even good in many cases) as long as the change makes sense for the character. It‚Äôs similar to how a lot of comic book movie adaptations take creative liberties and alter the source material to better serve the movie. The changes that work still serve the story without completely destroying the character or disrespecting the source material if it deviates wildly (changing Namor‚Äôs origins, making Wong a partner to Doctor Strange rather than a butler, making the Mandarin an actor originally) while bad changes will just straight up ruin a character for no good reason or to be edgy (Batman using guns, Taskmaster having no independent thought and just being a weapon, Deadpool having his mouth sewn shut).

For Kratos, this is a change that made sense and felt like natural character progression. Indiana Jones (in the final 2 movies) didn‚Äôt feel that way. They just felt like the character randomly changed for reasons that didn‚Äôt really feel natural for the character or franchise.
